GS General Industrial Capex Tracker
Where data is available, we conduct bottom- up analysis of capex expectations for c.4k companies across 26 end markets - c.60% of our multi- industry coverage top line (ex- construction tracker).
Our analysis covers c.3tn of capex.

We look at the fundamentals of investment by end market: Physical need (capacity utilization, age of equipment, replacement demand); availability of funds to finance investment internally and externally (leverage, cash generation).

We conduct in- depth analysis of the nuances in each end market (e.g., technology shifts, regional trends, regulatory drivers), near- term developments and company read- across (including top- line correlation).

We adjust the capex trackers by accounting for the biases in capex estimates by consensus observed over the past c.20 years. We achieve this by looking at how estimates changed with respect to the actual reported numbers throughout the year in up, down and through cycles. We then apply the adjustment factor to the current capex estimates to arrive at the adjusted capex tracker.

Regional and End-Market Barometer Summary (Q3 2025 vs Q2 2025)
We track \(700+\) short- cycle, high- frequency monthly data points and map the optimal combination to an implied organic growth number for each of the companies we cover.

We divide the monthly YoY growth indicators into respective regions and then take an average of the data points weighted by end- market exposures within that region. This creates a regional YoY growth estimate for the quarter.

We then weigh these regions by geographical exposure to create an aggregate YoY growth figure per regional end market. Note we take a simple average of monthly data to generate a quarterly estimate for each data series.

For business confidence indicators (PMIs, IFO, ISM, ABI, etc.), we produce a weighted index of the respective regions by the company- specific geographic exposure. We then do a simple linear regression of this index against group organic growth, historically, to calculate the implied relationship.

Plans to inject up to €1tn into the country's military and infrastructure to boost the EU's rearmament efforts.- Exemption of defence spending, broadly defined, above \(1\%\) of GDP from the debt brake limits.- Planned defence spending is about \(1.25\%\) of GDP in the main budget, of which \(0.25\%\) would be exempted from the debt brake limits.- Defence spending to include expenditures on intelligence agencies and aid to countries under attack (Ukraine).- EUR 500bn off- budget fund to finance additional infrastructure and climate protection investments over 12 years; EUR 100bn dedicated "Climate and transformation fund".- An increase in the allowed deficit limits for the federal states to \(0.35\%\) , up from \(0.0\%\) currently.

Germany's newly passed budget expansion- Germany's budget draft for 2025 and outlook for 2026- 29, recently approved on June 24, reveal a considerable increase in both investment and defence spending.- Defence spending is projected to reach \(3.4\%\) of GDP by 2029. However, these plans also entail a larger- than- anticipated federal deficit, with \(3.3\%\) expected in 2025 and \(3.6 - 3.8\%\) in the following years.

We have created a qualitative framework to assess end markets where we see characteristics that might attract more Chinese competition (first locally in China, then in other EMs and with a longer timeline potentially in Europe) based on:

- Level of domestic Chinese competitors being technologically already closer to DM players- Sizeable local Chinese competitors already exist- The relevance of aftermarket and post sale services is less significant- Distributors do not play the role of gatekeeper of OEMs in the market- Cost of failure of equipment (downtime) is negligible compared to total cost of the product- Chinese players have already started taking share domestically- Market size is large- Margin level is high- Customer concentration is high, so customers can exert pressure on pricing- Upfront costs are high compared to total cost of ownership
Finally, we believe certain product categories that are considered of national interest might have strong barriers to entry for Chinese players, even when the conditions above are met.

Daniela Costa, Managing Director, joined Goldman Sachs in 2008 and covers Multi- Industry. She is also the Business Unit Leader for Industrials. Prior to joining Goldman Sachs, she worked at McKinsey & Co. Daniela has an MBA from Harvard Business School and a degree in Civil Engineering from Instituto Superior Tecnico.
